column4: I'm sure most are familiar with the dnsmasq technique to cache dns requests locally. I have not been successful in configuring this to work with a wireless device. Can someone offer some insight on what could be the issue? Seems it doesn't respond to wlan0 (but works great with eth0)
My AP is a little far away and I'm connected at 1Mb/s. This is causing dns resolving to be painfully slow. What are my options?
move the ap... add a wireless repeater, stronger wireless adapter
sure money is the answer to all problems, but there should be a fix applied to dnsmasq to work with wireless devices.
its not a matter of bandwidth its a matter of latency
is your dns server set to your routers ip?
yes.. it's the wireless latency that is causing the dns requests to drop and fail.
I've configured my dns to that of OpenDNS. all tests work fine except for the > ~200ms resolve time each request.
you could try a home made reflector to put on your ap's antenna although its likely the signal issue is on the adapters end
200ms isnt great but its not horrible
unfortunately I could not try that idea since I'm out of foil right now.
your sure that its dns that slowing things down correct?
positive. media is very responsive once it gets kicked into gear.
whats in /etc/resolv.conf
a list of my name servers. starting with localhost followed by the two opendns address and lastly my router's
if you do an nslookup which server responds to the request... more specifically is the first server in /etc/resolve.conf the one that responds
good hint. I see that opendns responds first.
if you move the computer closer to the AP does it work better?
I am unable to try that, since what is between my router and my desktop is terrain
try bypassing dns and open a site by ip to see if you have the same problem
I gave up hope with dnsmasq and configured dnscache. works great!!
